Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by a differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\), where M is a constant matrix. An external operator applies a transformation \\( h(x) = Qx \\) at time t, with Q also being a constant matrix, and we analyze its impact over various conditions.

If \\( h(x) \\) is applied to a vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\) without any further intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( h(x) \\) alters the initial conditions of the system from \\( x_0 \\) to \\( Qx_0 \\). Since the future state \\( x(t) \\) depends linearly on the initial conditions under the equation \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\), the state at time T, \\( e^{MT}Qx_0 \\), will differ from \\( e^{MT}x_0 \\) unless Q commutes with \\( e^{MT} \\) for system-specific reasons.
